io.inversion

  • java.lang.Object

    CosmosDb, DynamoDb, ElasticsearchDb, FirehoseDb, JdbcDb, RedisDb, S3Db

      • select

        public abstract Results<Rows.Row> select(Collection collection,
                                         java.util.List<Term> queryTerms)
                                  throws java.lang.Exception
        Finds all rows that match the supplied query terms. IMPORTANT The Result object contains a list of Row objects. Unlike the Rows class all Row objects in the Result do not have to share the same keys.
        Parameters:
        table -
        queryTerms -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • upsert

        public abstract java.util.List<java.lang.String> upsert(Collection collection,
                                                        java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> rows)
                                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Upserts the key/values pairs for each row into the underlying data source as a PATCH, not as a full replacement. Keys that are not supplied in the call but that exist in the row in the target DB should not be modified. Each row should minimally contain key value pairs that satisfy one of the tables unique index constraints allowing an update to take place instead of an insert if the row already exists in the underlying data source. IMPORTANT #1 - implementors should note that the keys on each row may be different. IMPORTANT #2 - strict POST/PUT vs POST/PATCH semantics are implementation specific. For example, a RDBMS backed implementation may choose to upsert only the supplied client supplied keys effectively making this a POST/PATCH operation. A document store that is simply storing the supplied JSON may not be able to do partial updates elegantly and replace existing documents entirely rendering this a POST/PUT.
        Parameters:
        table -
        rows -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • patch

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> patch(Collection collection,
                                               java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> rows)
                                        throws java.lang.Exception

      • delete

        public abstract void delete(Collection collection,
                            java.util.List<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> indexValues)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Deletes rows identified by the unique index values from the underlying data source. IMPORTANT implementors should note that the keys on each row may be different. The keys should have come from a unique index, meaning that the key/value pairs for each row should uniquely identify the row...however there is no guarantee that each row will reference the same index.
        Parameters:
        table -
        indexValues -
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
